thread.title: Affinity Equity Partners mandates Goldman, Deutsche for Tegel Foods IPO
thread.title_full: Affinity Equity Partners mandates Goldman, Deutsche for Tegel Foods IPO | afr.com

author: ANZ global infrastructure head David Byrne to leave bank
title: Affinity Equity Partners mandates Goldman, Deutsche for Tegel Foods IPO
text:
Tegel is an integrated producer, processor, marketer and distributor of chicken and turkey products and is expected to be worth as much as $NZ900 million. by Sarah Thompson Anthony Macdonald Jake Mitchell Affinity Equity Partners has hired Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank to advise on the proposed initial public offering of its New Zealand poultry business, Tegel Foods.
Tegel is an integrated producer, processor, marketer and distributor of chicken and turkey products and is expected to be worth as much as $NZ900 million. The IPO timetable is being finalised but it's understood marketing will start shortly.
The company is majority-owned by private equity firm Affinity, with Tegel management also on the shareholder register with a less than 10 per cent stake.
Street Talk revealed last month that Affinity had contacted investment banks, seeking pitches for the company's float.
The private equity investor took face-to-face pitches last week, sources said, interviewing those investment banks with a strong Australian and New Zealand equities business.
Goldman and Deutsche, which has a partnership with one of New Zealand's biggest retail brokers Craigs Investment Partners, fit the bill.
Affinity bought the company from Pacific Equity Partners in 2011 for $NZ605 million, trumping bids from US fund Paine & Partners and Thailand's largest private company, The Charoen Pokphand Group. Macquarie Capital advised on this deal.
A Tegel divestment would cap a something of a purple patch for the Asia-based Affinity.
 The team, led by Brett Sutton, has closed $3 billion of Australian deals in the past 12-months, including two proprietary transactions. It identified the protein theme early and has moved on to scooping up unloved corporate spin-offs - acquiring a 35 per cent stake in Virgin Australia Holding's Velocity frequent flyer division for $336 million in October 2014, followed by the purchase of Nine Entertainment Co's Live division in April for about $640 million.
Affinity also sold Primo Smallgoods to Brazilian meat processing giant JBS for a blockbuster $1.45 billion in November 2014.
